G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” and is liable for actual and statutory damages where such interference is found, including the possibility of multiple damages and reasonable attorney’s fees.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all times relevant to this Complaint, Defendant has been the landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239 and has been responsible for maintaining the Premises and providing utilities and services required by law and by the rental agreement.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all times relevant to this Complaint, Defendant has been the landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239 and has been responsible for maintaining the Premises and providing utilities and services required by law and by the rental agreement.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 212, § 3 because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Boston Municipal Court and the claims arise under the statutes and common law of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment).

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Massachusetts law and regulations require landlords to provide heat sufficient to maintain minimum temperatures in residential dwellings during the heating season.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: As a matter of Massachusetts law, all residential tenancies include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes and applies an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty" of quiet enjoyment in favor of residential tenants, and treats its breach as a basis for constructive eviction and a defense to rent. The court analyzes when a landlord’s conduct constitutes a breach of that implied covenant under Massachusetts law. However, the excerpt does not explicitly tie the covenant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 by name or state that it exists in *all* residential tenancies, so support for the statutory and universal scope aspects is somewhat inferential rather than explicit.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). ... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 103\u201.proposition: The fact that the heat never went completely off does not excuse Defendant’s failure to provide heat that meets legal requirements and does not prevent liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 103\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 in the context of willful/reckless failure to provide essential services and interference with quiet enjoyment, but it does not address heat service at all, nor any argument that partial or inadequate heat might avoid liability. The case involves repeated flooding and sanitary code violations, not heating deficiencies, so it cannot be authority for the specific proposition that the landlord’s liability under § 14 persists even where the heat never went completely off.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 103\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The objectives of these statutes go beyond deterrence of intentional wrongdoing; unsanitary conditions in an apartment cause harm to the occupants whether the landlord has acted intentionally, negligently, or innocently… In the present case, we need not extend the scope of § 14 beyond recklessness, and penalties for reckless conduct are well within the constraints of due process.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide and maintain adequate and code‑compliant heat during the winter heating season, despite notice of recurring failures and despite his legal obligations under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and 105 CMR 410.201, constitutes a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the Premises.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season, as required by the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.201), “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment” under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court also emphasizes that liability does not depend on intent or financial ability, but on the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct, which aligns with characterizing such a failure as a substantial and unreasonable interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Although the opinion does not cite G.L. c. 111 §§ 127A–127L by number, it expressly ties the violation to State Sanitary Code heating requirements.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.raw_text: Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.proposition: The implied warranty of habitability recognized in Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., including 105 CMR 410.201 requiring adequate heat, form part of Plaintiff’s tenancy and define the minimum standards of habitability that the landlord must meet.
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.support_reasoning: Justice Quirico’s concurrence/dissent expressly states that (1) statutes, regulations, and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose obligations on landlords for the benefit of tenants, and (2) by renting, the landlord impliedly agrees the unit complies with those legal standards, specifically including the State Sanitary Code. He further emphasizes that such minimum standards of fitness for human habitation (as defined by Code provisions) cannot be waived and form part of the tenancy. This aligns with the proposition that the implied warranty of habitability in Hemingway and the State Sanitary Code, including its heat requirement, are incorporated into the tenancy and define the landlord’s minimum obligations.
Hemingway v. Boston Housing Auth., 363 M.relevant_excerpt: As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct occurred after Plaintiff took possession of the Premises and was therefore within the scope of G.L. c. 186, § 14, as interpreted in Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102–104, and Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns conduct occurring after the tenant has taken possession and being actionable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 as interpreted in Simon and this case. In Doe, the SJC expressly applies § 14 to the landlord’s omissions in responding to ongoing drug-related activity in common areas during the tenancy, treating that post‑possession interference as potentially within the statute’s scope and remanding for fact‑finding. Thus, the case is proper authority that post‑possession landlord conduct (or nonfeasance) can constitute a violation of § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

Dukes v. Durante, 192 Mass. App. Ct. 110.proposition: The pattern of substandard heat and resulting conditions was sufficiently serious to amount to a constructive eviction in whole or in part, although Plaintiff, for reasons of necessity, remained in possession of the Premises.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The failure to provide adequate heat also constitutes a violation of the State Sanitary Code and G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L, which has been recognized as evidence of both breach of the implied warranty of habitability and breach of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations and expressly ties them to statutory remedies under G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L and c. 239, § 8A, and to the measure of rent due. It argues that statutory code violations should define the landlord’s implied obligations, but it does not specifically identify failure to provide adequate heat, nor does it frame such violations as evidence of a breach of quiet enjoyment. The majority’s habitability analysis (not reproduced here) is the more likely source of any connection between code violations and implied warranty/quiet enjoyment; this separate opinion does not clearly establish the precise proposition claimed.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code... The Code…fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units… By G. L. c. 111, § 127C… and § 127H… a tenant may file a petition… to enforce compliance with the Code by the landlord… As the first step… I would… hold… that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards.”}

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly treats the lack of adequate heat and hot water as violations of the State Sanitary Code and as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, supporting the first part of the proposition. However, the case does not address or analyze G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L as independent grounds, nor does it discuss or apply a claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. Its focus is on rent abatement for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, not quiet enjoyment, so it does not support the full, combined proposition as stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

L. c. 111, § 127L … the statute at that time limited the withholdings to a total of two months’ rent….

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, Defendant is liable to Plaintiff for her actual and consequential damages, and, because Defendant’s conduct was at least in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s statutory and sanitary code rights after repeated notice, Defendant is liable for multiple damages (up to three times actual damages) and reasonable attorney’s fees and costs, even though Plaintiff is self‑represented.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does construe G.L. c. 186, § 14 as providing liability for “actual and consequential damages” and a minimum of three months’ rent, and it confirms a mandatory award of reasonable attorney’s fees when a violation is established. However, it does not address multiple (double or treble) damages for reckless or knowing violations—§ 14 only provides a choice between actual/consequential damages and three months’ rent, not up to three times actual damages. The opinion also assumes representation by counsel and discusses fees only in that context; it does not consider whether a self-represented plaintiff may recover attorney’s fees. Thus, the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”

Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).proposition: In addition, G.L. c. 93A, § 9 and related consumer protection caselaw (including Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985)), while not separately pled here as a cause of action, reinforce the strong public policy in Massachusetts against unfair and deceptive acts and practices by residential landlords and underscore the seriousness of Defendant’s failures to comply with basic health and safety obligations.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).support_reasoning: The proposition uses Leardi not to establish a freestanding c. 93A cause of action in the case at hand, but to invoke Massachusetts’ strong public policy under c. 93A against unfair and deceptive practices by residential landlords, particularly where basic tenant protections are undermined. Leardi squarely holds that inclusion of deceptive, unlawful lease clauses regarding habitability and sanitary-code rights violates c. 93A and constitutes an “injury” even absent actual damages, and highlights the court’s “zealous” protection of tenants and the seriousness of landlord noncompliance with legal obligations. That directly reinforces the public-policy point for which the case is cited.
Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151 (1985).relevant_excerpt: “We further note that tenants are among those for whose benefit the Consumer Protection Act was passed… and we have traditionally been zealous in protecting tenants who have shown that their landlords, for whatever reason, fail to fulfil the obligations imposed upon them by statute and decisional law. … Tenants have suffered injury as a result of the inclusion of several illegal clauses in the standard lease agreement. Reasonable relief, ‘in relation to the injury,’ would only be afforded by an agreement to remove the offensive clauses.”
